abstracts.cdata!:
The report covers the environmental
            assessment for the Community-Based Rural Development
            Project, aimed at poverty reduction, and sustainable rural
            development, by providing socioeconomic infrastructure, to
            increase the productivity of rural assets. Burkina Faso is
            essentially a semi-arid, but also an agricultural country,
            thus its fragile natural resource base, and extensive
            farming practices are accelerating its degradation. It is
            imperative that the assessment be implemented at the
            earliest stages of subproject implementation, and that
            beneficiaries be trained, introducing at the same time
            improved sanitation practices at the village level. An
            awareness campaign should limit shallow pollution, and
            inappropriate waste disposal. It is expected that
            construction of rural, and feeder roads through forest, and
            pastoral zones, in addition to small-scale dams, and piped
            water systems for large villages, will adversely impact the
            environment. Mitigating measures follow. Project
            construction call for the elimination of lateral ditches
            along the road, instead, new water channels would enhance
            water accessibility to local populations. Construction
            material will be humidified to prevent dust pollution, and
            re-vegetation will prevent soil erosion. Improved drainage
            infrastructure should restore water transfers, regulating
            the wetlands, and, the downstream portion of road drainage
            should prevent accelerated formation of gullies, and erosion
            alongside. Although the engineering design will limit
            deforestation, and vegetative losses, ecosystems and wetland
            management will ensure tree planting and re-vegetation as needed.
